The diagnosis is confirmed by the FOXP3 gene mutation, which causes defective regulatory T cells (Tregs). FOXP3 is essential for Treg development and function. Without functional Tregs, there is loss of immune tolerance leading to autoimmune phenomena. The classic manifestations include: 1) Enteropathy (chronic diarrhea), 2) Endocrinopathy (most commonly type 1 diabetes and thyroid disease), and 3) Dermatitis (eczema). Hemorrhagic diathesis occurs in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ocular telangiectasias in ataxia-telangiectasia, and retained primary teeth in hyper-IgE syndrome. Autoimmune endocrinopathy is the hallmark complication of IPEX syndrome."}
